entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
01/11 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-ninety-third edition:

Ramón
  • vim-nerdtree-tabs - A Vim plugin allowing NERDtree and tabs to work together.
  • Memrise - Free-ish platform for learning spoken languages, with videos of natives speaking!
  • Vienna BEAMers - A bi-weekly Elixir study group held here in Vienna.
Markus
  • Ruby 2.4 Released: Faster Hashes, Unified Integers and Better Rounding
  • How to ask good questions - An essential guide.
  • Writing software is hard - We all know it, but we’re still shocked when we encounter bad software.
Max
  • Building an Umbrella Project - Awesome talk on Elixir (& Phoenix) umbrella apps vs. microservices.
  • rubocop_runner - Nifty little tool used at Runtastic to prevent devs from committing non-Rubocop-confirm code.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
01/04 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-ninety-second edition:

Markus
  • Jessica Rose - Imposter Syndrome and Individual Competence
  • Is the Ballmer Peak real? - From this XKCD comic.
  • Choose an open source license - It’s a new year, you might have made a resolution to make a new open source project, and you’ll need a license for it.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/28 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-ninety-first edition:

Markus
  • Why is a BasicObject a Range?
  • Just because you have been doing it doesn’t mean you are doing it right
  • 10 Modern Software Over-Engineering Mistakes

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/21 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-ninetieth edition:

Markus
  • Web Design: The First Hundred Years with Maciej Ceglowski
  • I’m a boring programmer (and proud of it) - We’re all suckers for excitement, but in your job, being boring can be a big advantage.
  • Kill all the mutants - a deep dive into mutation testing and how the Mutant gem works

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/14 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-ninth edition:

Markus
  • The Best Password Managers - The Wirecutter looks at the best password managers out there. If you don’t use one already, take a look, then pick one.
  • Decrypting TLS Browser Traffic With Wireshark – The Easy Way! - Sometimes, you do need to debug TLS traffic. With this trick, you can even do it when you use certificate pinning.
  • A Comprehensive Guide to Terraform - Terraform is a tool to programatically provide & manage infrastructure - both servers and software.
Max
  • DRY up your domain models using a struct table - Unconventional but super neat refactoring technique.
  • Clean your desk - Second in a series of posts causing shitstorms at Amazon (quite rightly).
  • I Think It’s a Fish - Funny, trolly episode of the Bike Shed with insights on day-to-day (open source) work.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
12/07 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-eighth edition:

Markus
  • How much memory is my process using? - Sounds like an easy question that can be suprisingly hard to answer.
  • Small Details, Big Impact By Yehuda Katz and Liz Baillie - Contains both programming and design examples.
  • A Precious Hour
Max
  • Jenn Schiffer at xoxo Festival - Awesome, funny, entertaining but somewhere also sad and serious talk vaguely about satire in tech.
  • The European Ruby Revolution - Interesting observations on the differences between the European and US Ruby community when it comes to the future of Ruby and a more diverse ecosystem.
  • Yarn Support - Rails 5.1 will support alternative solutions for managing assets: yarn and webpack.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/30 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-seventh edition:

Markus
  • Let Postgres Do The Work - A demo of how you can offload work onto PostgreSQL, which can have the nice side effect of making everything much faster.
  • A Rubyist looks at Crystal (Part 2) - Continuing from Part 1, this post goes deeper into the unique features Crystal has in relation to Ruby.
  • Inspecting C’s qsort Through Animation - Various sorting algorithms animated, showing nicely how they work internally.
Max
  • That Works?! - Talk on quines, the true (ninja) art of programming (e.g. rewriting any JS program using only six chars).
  • Introduction to Concurrency in Ruby - Talk showcasing various options for having Ruby do things simultaneously.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/23 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-sixth edition:

Markus
  • Level Up Your Security in Rails - Covers all the basics everyone (even if you don’t use Rails) should know.
  • Setting up a Postgres Sandbox - Sometimes, you need a PostgreSQL instance you can play around with & destroy stuff, without having to worry.
  • The Search For <Class:0x00000027b59290> - How the search for some weird output lead to the discovery of a bug.
Max
  • Why We Chose Turbolinks - Pragmatic reasoning on why one would choose to use Turbolinks in Phoenix.
  • How to run a Meetup - React Vienna’s Nik Graf with tips and lesson learned from running a meetup.
  • Tachyons - Functional, minimalistic CSS library build for fast page loading.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/16 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-fifth edition:

Laura
  • Finding time to become a better developer - It’s often hard to keep up with all the frameworks and languages without getting lost in them, so here’s a good overview of the things you should keep in mind.
  • A Rubyist’s Guide to Big-O Notation - Just what it says.
  • Consequences of an insightful algorithm - The Keynote from RubyConf 2015 by Carina C. Zona, on the ethics of using data in our systems, sometimes with unforeseen consequences.
Markus
  • How to Read Unfamiliar Code - A talk by Josh Matthews, going into general strategy when familiarizing yourself with an unknown codebase
  • How to Read Source Code - Aria Stewart on the same topic, using various bits of JavaScript to demonstrate how she reads source code
  • Over-engineering (the root of all evil)
Max
  • How Meetup Ditched Its Boys Club - Story of Meetup transforming their company to be a more diverse place.
  • 3 Days with Sandi Metz - Experience and lesson learned by a super stoked attendee of Sandi Metz‘ “POODNYC” course.
  • How to write an MVC framework in Ruby - Awesome tutorial on writing a Rack-based MVC framework from scratch.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/09 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-fourth edition:

Markus
  • Yes, Virginia, You Can Estimate That - When and how to estimate software projects.
  • Wasting Time TDDing The Wrong Things - Testing is good, but it won’t save you from having to think about design first.
  • Cognitive bias cheat sheet - Thinking is hard, and biases are everywhere.
Max
  • Concurrency for !Dummies - Smooth introduction to concurrency by the awesome Kerri Miller.
  • Purposes & Properties of Value Objects - Nice example-driven post by Luca Guidi on domain modeling with value objects.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
11/02 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-third edition:

Laura
  • The art of closing - Sometimes patches or pull requests on your Open Source projects just have to be closed. Here’s a few tips on how to do so gracefully.
  • Getting things done - Spoiler alert: focus and break things down.

Markus

  • The Inevitability of Being Hacked - When you hook up a (fake) toaster to the internet, it’ll be hacked pretty quickly.
  • The New Minimalism - Your minimalism is someone elses complexity.
  • Avoiding Distractions While Programming
Max
  • keight - Another fast Ruby web framework in the making.
  • Hash#compact and Hash#compact! - Ruby 2.4 includes faster (implemented in C) versions of some convenient ActiveSupport methods.
  • HexaPDF - Of vienna.rb-fame PDF library written in Ruby.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/26 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-second edition:

Markus
  • How To Accept Over-Engineering For What It Really Is - When does overengineering start?
  • How Rust Do? - A great introductory post explaining how to do things in Rust (and its ecosystem).
  • How Twitch uses PostgreSQL - Twitch runs a really big PostgreSQL cluster, and explains how they manage things.
Max
  • From Front End to Full Stack with Elixir and Phoenix - Beginner friendly introduction to functional programming in Elixir by Lauren Tan.
  • rocket - Slack-style emoji everywhere (on your Mac).
  • em-midori - EventMachine based web framework in the early stages of development.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/19 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eighty-first edition:

Markus
  • ripgrep is faster than {grep, ag, git grep, ucg, pt, sift} - ripgrep is a new search tool written in Rust, and this blog post goes into the details why its faster than the others (including benchmarks!)
  • How to be* a compiler — make a compiler with JavaScript - An excellent and well-written introduction to how compilers do their work (by teaching you to become one)
  • Reflections of an “Old” Programmer - Contains lots of excellent advice
Max
  • Fuck You Startup World - Hilarious, yet somehow also sad and alarming post on the state of the startup world and its ‘I-must-optimize-every-living-second’ lifestyle.
  • Atom 1.11 - Atom 1.11 is out, with lots of improvements (and a custom title bar).
  • Microservices @ Spotify - Some interesting insights on Spotify’s service- and team-setup.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/12 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-eightieth edition:

Laura
  • Coraline Ada Ehmke on CodeNewbie - A really insightful, intense and interesting episode of CodeNewbie about Social Justice.
  • linter-alex - An atom plugin to make writing gender-neutral and less inconsiderate.
  • How to find your first Open Source bug to fix - a very beginner-friendly, short guide to contributing to Open Source
Markus
  • How Dropbox securely stores your passwords - Dropbox has an interesting approach on how they store their passwords.
  • Security Design: Stop Trying to Fix the User - Bruce Schneier argues that user security education is often counterproductive.
  • Nanolaw with Daughter - A sci-fi short story about a possible lawsuit-filled future.
Max
  • How it feels to learn JavaScript in 2016 - Hilarious and somehow sad story on the current state of frontend development.
  • whirly - Terminal spinners for your Ruby CLI.
  • typora - Super neat, minimalistic and promising looking Markdown editor (free during beta).
Gerald
  • Vienna.rb Goes Minima - Vienna.rb Site Redesign using “Plain Vanilla” Jekyll w/ Gem-Packaged Minima Theme.
  • Jekyll 3.3 - What’s News? - Gem-Packaged Themes Now w/ Assets, New relative_url, absolute_url filters, and much more.
  • Qk/Quik Gem-Packaged Jekyll Theme Starter Scaffold - a new scaffold for gem-packaged jekyll themes that mirrors/copies the jekyll new-theme command.
  • Dr Jekyll’s Top 22 Themes - top 22 jekyll themes ranked by github stars; and the winner is…

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
10/05 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-seventy-ninth edition:

Markus
  • The Ruby Community and Reputation
  • Ruby vs Python, the Definitive FAQ - In case you’re not familiar with the differences, here’s a great overview.
  • What else can you do with a Big Dumb Booster? - Now that SpaceX has announced their Interplanetary Transport System, Sci-Fi writer Charles Stross thinks about possible other uses – both practical and more exotic

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
09/28 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-seventy-eighth edition:

Markus
  • Yes, Virginia, You Can Estimate That - When and How to Estimate Software Projects
  • Why Luck Matters More Than You Might Think - Luck is often a bigger factor than anyone likes to admit.
  • Building fast.com - Fast.com is a simple internet speed test that runs on Netflix' infrastructure.
Max
  • Pairing with Junior Developers - Old but still valid guide on pairing with junior devs.
  • Brew Bundle - “Bundler” for Homebrew, a neat tool for bootstrapping new machines.
  • rbenv - Another Ruby version manager (I just switched from chruby and love it!)

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
09/21 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-seventy-seventh edition:

Markus
  • A mistake is just a moment in time - Not every mistake needs correcting.
  • Using security features to do bad things - Just because a feature increases security doesn’t mean it too can be abused for nefarious purposes.
  • Why Star Trek’s Prime Directive could never be enforced
Max
  • Suture - A nifty gem to help you refactor legacy code.
  • Succession - Awesome example driven talk by the awesome Katrina Owen on the thoughts and epiphanies of refactoring.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
09/14 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-seventy-sixth edition:

Laura
  • Intro to databases - … for people who don’t know a whole lot about them
  • A whole new GitHub Universe - GitHub just unveiled a ton of new features at GitHub Universe
Markus
  • Oh shit, git! - First git aid for when something’s screwed up
  • Julie Zhuo on the Lessons of Good Design - Her advice is applicable to programming as well
  • On Beta Testing - Brent Simmons explains how they ran the Vesper beta test, and what distinguishes a good beta test
Max
  • I’m an Adult and I Choose Java - Awesome episode of my favorite podcast, “demystifying” the world of Android development, Kotlin and Sean’s scooter-wifi.
  • Resumable File Uploads in Ruby - Interesting background information on tooling choices when developing tus-ruby-server (a tool to tackle large file uploads in Ruby).
  • Pry: A Simple Start - Into to some nifty features of my favorite REPL: pry

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
09/07 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-seventy-fifth edition:

Laura
  • How do you decide what to work on? - Julia Evans on coming up with a focus at work.
  • The Imposter’s handbook - A book for “self-taught developers who have never taken the time to learn foundational concepts”.
Markus
  • CloudFlare, SSL and unhealthy security absolutism - Security is not an absolute state, it’s always relative. And any improvements to it are beneficial.
  • The “network partitions are rare” fallacy
  • The Underestimated Merits of Copying Someone Else’s Work - Copying other’s work can be a useful learning tool. Just don’t claim the copied work as your own.
Max
  • mruby CLI - Forget about Go, build native commandline apps in Ruby and ship them as a binary.
  • Deoptimizing Ruby - What’s this thing about “deoptimizing” and what role does Truffle play in it?
  • Examining The Internals Of The Rails Request/Response Cycle - What people call “Rails magic”.

entry.title: Picks / What the vienna.rb Team Thinks Is Worth Sharing This Week
entry.content:
08/31 Picks!

In a series on this website we’ll entertain YOU with our picks - or: what we think is worth sharing - every week. Books, articles, gems, fun stuff… you’re in for an eclectic mix! So, here’s for the one-hundred-seventy-fourth edition:

Laura
  • Elixir for Rubyists - With Elixir being the new cool kid in town, a look at its properties and features — and what that means for us Rubyists.
Ramón
  • Hyperterm (Mac-only for now) - An Electron-based alternative to Terminal.app and iTerm
  • Learn CSS Flexbox in 3 Minutes
  • Git’s Patch Mode All the Way - An overview of git’s patching prowess. I had no idea you could stash patches!
Markus
  • Writer, Interrupted - Charles Stross writes science fiction novels for a living. Turns out, writing novels and writing programs are very similar in one regard: Interruptions are deadly. Pair with: And it’s gone —The true cost of interruptions.
  • The Treacherous Optimization - What the author of Hex Fiend learned when he tried to be faster than grep.
  • Hunting for great names in programming - You know the joke…
Max
  • Cube Composer - Tiny, addictive browser game around array manipulation logics.
  • The Laila and Brenda Show - New podcast from our friends at Thoughtbot focussing on the people behind software.
  • From monolithics to microservices - A developer’s path to establishing solid principles, loaded with links to interesting further resources.
